awd_titl_txt: Planar photonic crystals for ultra-broadband ultrasound detection and generation
awd_abstract_narration:
Ultrasound plays an important role in many applications, including health care (e.g., clinical diagnostics, medical therapy, and surgery) and industrial monitoring (e.g., non-destructive detection and material characterization).  In all these applications, transducers are critically needed for detection and generation of ultrasound.  However, the current ultrasonic transducers are limited in detectability, spatial resolution, and bandwidth, which seriously hinder the performance of existing ultrasonic techniques. This award will support fundamental research on novel artificially designed low-dimensional periodic photonic structures (i.e., planar photonic crystals) for ultrasound detection and generation.  This work is expected to open up new avenues for the development of novel ultrasound transducers, which can potentially overcome the fundamental limitations encountered with conventional ultrasonic technologies. Various disciplines including physics, material science, and medicine are expected to benefit from different facets of the proposed research.  This award is expected to help create a new generation of students equipped with knowledge of emerging technologies in nanophotonics and advanced materials.  In addition, this award will also help broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in research and enrich the learning experience of students with innovative projects in an interdisciplinary curriculum integrated with the research findings.

Through combined analytical, numerical, and experimental studies, the overall goal of this work is to achieve a fundamental understanding of the photonic-acoustic responses and slow light effect in planar photonic crystals (PPCs), and to use this understanding to develop novel PPC based transducers with significantly enhanced performance and capabilities for ultrasound detection and generation.  This research is expected to enrich the knowledge in the growing field of nanophotonics and lead to new methodologies for ultrasound detection and generation with PPCs. The unique properties of PPCs, including high quality factor (Q-factor) resonance, multimode photo-mechanical response, and immunity to thermal interference, will be investigated. These properties give PPCs a clear advantage over existing ultrasonic sensors for ultrasound detection.  The award will lead to the development of a new class of PPC based ultrasonic sensors with capabilities of ultra-broadband detection, high sensitivity, and high spatial-resolution. Furthermore, the slow light effect in PPCs for enhancing light-matter interactions will be investigated; this will enable the development of novel PPC based ultrasound generators with significantly enhanced energy transfer efficiency. In addition, this award is expected to lead to the development of a novel optical fiber based nano-imprinting technique, for enabling scalable, inexpensive, and high-precision batch fabrication of on-fiber PPC devices and on-chip PPC arrays.

por.por_cntn:
Planar photonic crystals (PPCs), which are artificially designed low-dimensional periodic structures, can offer unprecedented opportunities to manipulate light-matter interactions at nanoscale level. These structures can be engineered to have unique optical properties, making them an ideal platform for the exploitation of novel physical phenomena and new functional devices applied in various fields. The overall goal of this work is to achieve a fundamental understanding of photonic-acoustic responses and slow light effect in PPCs, and to use this understanding to develop novel PPC based transducers with significantly enhanced performance and capabilities for ultrasound detection and generation.

Through analytical, numerical, and experimental studies, a fundamental understanding of photonic-acoustic responses and slow light effect in PPCs have been achieved. This enables the development of novel modalities for ultrasound detection and generation. These modalities have the potential to overcome the fundamental limitations encountered in conventional ultrasonic transducers and lead to transformative advances on ultrasonic techniques that can impact many fronts.  A new class of PPCs based ultrasonic sensors have been developed, with capabilities of ultra-broadband detection, high sensitivity and high spatial-resolution. Furthermore, by using the slow light effect in PPCs for enhancing light-matter interactions, novel PPC based ultrasound generators have been investigated to achieve improved energy transfer efficiency. In addition, a novel nano-imprinting technique based on an optical fiber mold has been developed, which enables scalable, inexpensive, and high-precision batch fabrication of on-fiber PPC devices. Various disciplines including physics, material science, and medicine are expected to benefit from different facets of the proposed research.

This project could impact many fronts, such as health care (e.g., ultrasonic imaging diagnosis and therapy) and industry applications (e.g., non-destructive damage detection). For example, the novel sensing modalities can potentially help overcome the detection limit encountered by the current medical imaging techniques, which could lead to future breakthroughs in detection of fetal diseases (e.g., cancers). The potential of using the unique slow-light enhanced ultrasound generation could lead to future advances to therapy and surgery techniques, where high-frequency, high-intensity ultrasound is highly desirable for achieving high accuracy cellular therapy as well as surgery treatment over single tissue layers, micro-tumors, and micro-vasculatures. Many industry applications can potentially benefit from this project, including nondestructive testing, material characterization, process monitoring, on-line quality control, etc, where improving the measurement accuracy and capability is highly desirable .

By integrating research with education, the learning experience of students has been enriched with innovative projects in an interdisciplinary curriculum integrated with the findings of this work. Three Ph.D. students and one postdoc research have been supported by this work.  This project has provided them interdisciplinary research experience in terms of nanofabrication, modeling of optical systems, and hands-on experiments.
